description: The noun is from Middle English swingel, from Old English swingel, swingelle (“whip, scourge”), equivalent to swing +‎ -le. Related to Middle Dutch swingel, swengel, Dutch zwingel, zwengel. Doublet of swingel.
The verb is from Middle English swingelen, from the noun. Related to Middle Dutch swingelen, swengelen.

entries.meaning: An implement used to separate the fibres of flax by beating them; a scutch.
The swinging part of a flail, especially that which is used on the grain in threshing; the swiple.

verbs.description: swingle (third-person singular simple present swingles, present participle swingling, simple past and past participle swingled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To beat or flog, especially for extracting the fibres from flax stalks; to scutch.
examples: The first operation in dressing flax is to swingle or beat it, in order to detach it from the harle or skimps.

verbs.description: swingle (third-person singular simple present swingles, present participle swingling, simple past and past participle swingled)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, dialect) To swing for pleasure.
